question: When to choose IVF
answer: Blocked or Damaged Fallopian Tubes, Male Infertility, Advanced Maternal Age, Endometriosis, Previous Unsuccessful Treatments, Fertility Preservation, Recurrent Miscarriages, Unexplained Infertility

question: How IVF Benefits Aspiring Couples?
answer: IVF works where other infertility treatments fail, Improves the chances of conception, Has a higher success rate when compared to other fertility treatments

question: what is the difference between IVF and IUI?
answer: Intrauterine insemination is a simple and less invasive fertility procedure usually done without anaesthesia or surgery. This fertility program is designed to increase the chance of the sperm reaching the egg.whereas IVF, short for In Vitro Fertilization, is one of the more advanced fertility treatments out there. It starts with hormone shots to help the ovaries produce more eggs than usual. Then, through a minor surgical procedure, the mature eggs are collected.

question: IVF or ivf
answer: IVF is a large chain of fertility and infertility treatment clinics in India, founded in 1988 by Dr. Ajay Murdia. With over 200 centers across the country, IVF offers a wide range of services, including In Vitro Fertilization (IVF), Intrauterine Insemination (IUI), and ICSI.

question: What services or test are offered at IVF centers? or what are the different types or services/test provided by ivf?
answer: IVF offers a variety of services and advanced tests to support fertility, pregnancy, and reproductive health. Here are some of the key ones:Test:1. Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) Test – Assess ovarian reserve, 2. Hormonal Profile Panel – Check hormone balance, 3. Transvaginal Pelvic Ultrasound – Visualize ovaries, 4. Azoospermia Panel – Detect sperm absence, 5. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing) – Screen fetal abnormalities, 6. sFlt-1/PlGF Ratio – Predict pre-eclampsia risk, Services:, 1. Endometrial Receptivity Analysis (ERA) – Determine implantation timing, 2. Genetic Testing (PGT-A / PGT-M) – Identify genetic disorders, 3. Semen Analysis – Evaluate sperm quality, 4. Sperm DNA Fragmentation Test – Measure DNA integrity, 5. Embryo Glue – Enhance embryo implantation, 6. Sperm Sorting Device – Select healthy sperm, 7. Laser Assisted Hatching – Aid embryo hatching, 8. Blastocyst Culture – Grow advanced embryos, 9. LIT (Lymphocyte Immunotherapy) – Improve immune tolerance, 10. TESA (Testicular Sperm Aspiration) – Retrieve testicular sperm

question: What is IVF?
answer: A treatment where eggs and sperm are fertilized in a lab, and the embryo is placed in the uterus to help pregnancy

question: When is the right time to start IVF treatment?
answer: Your doctor will explain the best time to start the treatment after the initial consultation, examination and blood tests. Your clinician may start your treatment on the 2nd or 3rd day of your period.

question: When should I opt for IVF?
answer:
The IVF procedure can be prescribed in cases where the other fertility treatments have failed, or if the chances of a successful pregnancy are higher with this method than with any other treatment.
If there are no contraindications, the procedure can be carried out simply at the request of the couple by considering that precise time as the right time for IVF.

question: In which cases is IVF performed?
answer:
Tubal-peritoneal factor 
   Violation of the patency of the fallopian tubes leads to the fact that the egg cannot penetrate the uterine cavity. In this case, you can either try to restore patency using a surgical laparoscopic operation or perform IVF and implant an already developing embryo into the uterine cavity.
Male Factor
This diagnosis is made when the quality of sperm is not high enough. If the number of healthy active sperm is too low to conceive a healthy child, it is better to resort to ART treatments like IVF, IUI, ICSI, etc.
 Endometriosis
Mild forms of endometriosis usually respond to surgery and hormonal treatment. If, after the therapy, pregnancy does not occur, then the doctor sends the couple for an IVF procedure.
Age-related infertility
Age plays a vital role when we talk about deciding the right time for IVF. With this factor of infertility, it is better to supplement the standard IVF procedure with ICSI and assisted hatching methods.
Anovulation
Anovulation is usually treated with simpler methods, such as hormonal stimulation combined with IUI. But if it’s unsuccessful, you can always use the IVF method.
Unexplained infertility
If it is not possible to establish an accurate diagnosis, and the therapy is unsuccessful, then the doctor may advise the couple to resort to the IVF procedure.

question: How does the IVF process work?
answer: In this process, the female egg is taken out under anaesthesia and fertilized with the husband’s sperm in the lab. The embryo formed after 3-5 days is transferred back to the uterus.

question: How long does the egg collection/pickup procedure take?
answer: The time duration of this procedure completely depends upon the number of follicles that are required to be aspirated. Normally, it takes about 5-10 minutes.

question: Is IVF safe?
answer: IVF is very safe and not that painful because the injections used for IVF are purified and injected in subcutaneous form. The egg collection process is done under light sedation which is also not painful. At the time of embryo transfer, anaesthesia is not given because it is a 2 to 5-minute process which hardly causes any pain. If done under expert care, IVF can turn out to be a very safe and easy procedure.

question: Is IVF painful?
answer: Every patient is different; therefore, the process will differ from patient to patient. However, when it comes to IVF injections, they are thin and easy and do not require intervention. They can also be administered under anaesthesia if required. The egg collection process is done under light sedation which is also not painful. At the time of embryo transfer, anaesthesia is not given because it is a 2 to 5-minute process that hardly causes any pain.

question: Is the egg collection process painful?
answer: The procedure is not painful as it is done under light sedation. But, at times it may cause mild discomfort. At our clinic, we use mild anaesthesia administered through an IV route which relieves discomfort.

question: What is the success rate of IVF?
answer: Success rates strongly depend on the age of the patient, their condition, medical history and the line of treatment administered.

question: How many times can we try IVF?
answer: A couple can try IVF as many times as they want while keeping the treatment cost in mind.

question: Can we have our tests done at a nearby clinic?
answer: As long as you are in close contact with the clinician, having your tests done at a clinic near you, is feasible. Expert doctors from IVF work in many cities & 150+ IVF centres across India so that patients in far rural areas can also access the best fertility care with ease.

question: How long do I need to rest after embryo transfer?
answer: Resting 15-20 minutes after the transfer is usually sufficient. We suggest not doing heavy exercise and walking long distances during this period. Women who work at an office can work the next day and resume daily activities.

question: Can I exercise post-embryo transfer?
answer: Yes, walking and light aerobic exercises are okay but avoid lifting heavy weights and any strenuous exercises.

question: Can I continue routine activities after embryo transfer?
answer:
Even though an embryo is formed artificially in an IVF pregnancy, there is no difference from what happens in the natural cycle. The uterus accepts the embryo in the same way it accepts the naturally fertilised eggs.
It is important to understand that nature has a foolproof plan in everything including the reproductive system where the embryo attaches to the uterine lining very firmly regardless of whether it attaches naturally or artificially. Movements like walking around or even gravity, do not cause the embryo to detach and fall off.
Also, it is a total myth that bed rest after embryo transfer increases the success rate of IVF. Research has shown that patients who take complete bed rest after embryo transfer have less success in IVF as compared to patients who continue to do their routine activities. The main reason behind this is that patients who keep themselves engaged in some activities have lower stress levels which helps in increasing their IVF success. Therefore, the advice of bed rest after embryo transfer is exaggerated or unrealistic.

question: What are the dos and don'ts after embryo transfer?
answer:
Bed rest is not required after embryo transfer; avoid lifting heavy weights and any strenuous exercises.
Take a healthy diet inclusive of antioxidants and avoid outside food. 
Avoid using public washrooms and maintain proper hydration to avoid urinary tract infection.
Avoid stress and negative thoughts.
Take medications prescribed after embryo transfer properly.

question: What is the gap period between two unsuccessful cycles?
answer:
IVF is planned for the second time only after a thorough diagnosis and analysis of possible causes of failure. On an average, a woman is given 3 months for rehabilitation as an IVF cycle gap. During this time, the reproductive system is restored and prepares to receive a new fertilized egg. If after the first IVF, there was a frozen pregnancy, then in this case the rest period lasts about 6 months. In such a situation, there is always chronic endometritis, which needs careful treatment before planning a new pregnancy.
For the second attempt to be successful, sometimes it is enough to make some adjustments to the previous IVF protocol by adding a proper IVF cycle gap. In some cases, a long stimulation cycle is replaced with a short one or one hormonal preparation is changed for another, while in others, the dosage is changed.
If no specific complications were identified, and the first IVF attempt was carried out in a natural cycle, that is, hormonal stimulation was not used, then the artificial insemination procedure can be carried out after 2 weeks. This means that in the next menstrual cycle, doctors begin to monitor the dominant follicle and, when favourable conditions are achieved, they perform a puncture and egg collection.

question: How much does IVF cost?

At IVF, the cost of IVF/ICSI treatment starts from ₹1,00,000* per cycle. It is advisable to consult with our fertility specialist for customized treatment plan.
*IVF process, Injections, Egg Pickup, Embryo Transfer cost included. Cost of treatment depends on your test reports, type of treatment required, hormonal conditions etc. and may vary from couple to couple.

question: What makes IVF expensive?
answer: This method requires highly qualified personnel, a world-class laboratory and the latest technology in equipment. The equipment and materials used in an IVF lab are all imported and expensive. In addition, most of the materials used are disposable and in single-use format.

question: What is the cost of IUI treatment?
answer:
>The cost of the IUI Program at IVF starts from ₹5,000*.
*Cost of treatment depends on your test reports, type of treatment required, hormonal conditions etc. and may vary from couple to couple.

question: What is Intrauterine Insemination (IUI)?
answer: Intrauterine Insemination or IUI is one of the common techniques of ART (Assisted Reproductive Technology). It allows putting sperm directly into the female’s uterus. In this process, the processed (washed) sperm are used. The usage of this technique results in increasing the possibilities of conception.

question: How does ICSI work?
answer:
Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is a conventional IVF procedure where fertilization of the egg is achieved through a different approach. Generally, fertilization occurs when a sperm attaches itself to the egg and penetrates through the outer layer. For some reason, the sperm may fail to penetrate the egg. In such a condition, ICSI can be done along with IVF to achieve pregnancy. During ICSI, a single sperm is picked and injected directly into the egg.
ICSI is performed by an experienced embryologist using specialized instruments. Though ICSI is a precise procedure for fertilization to occur, required cellular events need to take place.

question: What treatments are available for low sperm count?
answer: Low sperm count is also known as Oligospermia. One may undergo ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection) where a single sperm is injected into a matured egg. Adapting this treatment helps to elevate the chances of conceiving. Besides this, ICSI is useful, especially in cases of male infertility, low sperm motility and poor sperm morphology.

question: What treatments are available for nil sperm count?
answer: There are procedures like TESA/TESE for men who do not have sperm in their semen. These include collecting tissue samples directly from the testes in different ways depending on the condition. If sperm is found in these tissue samples, then ICSI can be used to inseminate the eggs.

question: What is cryopreservation?
answer:
The cryopreservation procedure allows the freezing of eggs, sperm, or embryos for future use. Generally, in IVF, three types of cryopreservation techniques are followed.

(i) Oocyte cryopreservation or Egg Freezing-Oocyte cryopreservation allows you to use frozen eggs at any desired time later in the future. When you feel ready for pregnancy, you can use these preserved eggs to ensure a healthier pregnancy. This reduces your concerns about chromosomal abnormalities, which otherwise increase with age, especially when you are 35 or older. Frozen oocytes can be thawed and then combined with sperm in the clinical lab.(ii) Sperm Cryopreservation-It is a process of storing sperms for future use. It helps men to preserve their fertility who are about to have a treatment that can cause fertility issues such as cancer therapy, or prostate or testicular surgery. You can also opt for sperm freezing if you are at risk of exposure to chemicals or radiation. This procedure is also used in sperm banking.(iii) Embryo CryopreservationIn IVF, embryo cryopreservation is an excellent option for preserving fertility for future use. Many times the extra embryos from an IVF cycle are kept frozen for future use. Embryo cryopreservation provides you with another chance to get pregnant if IVF fails the first time. You will not have to go through the whole IVF procedure again.

question: What is the process of IVF?
answer: Sir, if due to any reason you are unable to conceive naturally, IVF can help. It’s a safe and common process where we take the husband’s sperm and the wife’s egg and fertilize them in a lab. Once the embryo forms, it is transferred into the woman’s uterus at the right time. This is known as IVF. The entire process usually takes about 1 to 1.5 months and involves around 5–6 visits. If you want to know more, we suggest visiting the center for a consultation. The doctor will explain your treatment process step by step based on your case.

answer: No sir, gender determination is strictly prohibited by Indian law. IVF strictly follows all legal and ethical guidelines and does not perform any such procedures. Also sir, we believe that every child—girl or boy—is equally precious. The most important thing is having a healthy baby, and we are here to help you achieve that dream safely and ethically.

question: What needs to be done in case of multiple miscarriages?
answer: We are truly sorry to hear about your experience. Multiple miscarriages can be caused by many factors such as weak endometrial lining, hormonal imbalance, or genetic issues. Please don’t worry—at IVF, we have advanced technology and a wide range of treatment options that may help you achieve a successful pregnancy. It’s important to consult with our doctor so they can evaluate your case and identify the exact reason for the miscarriages. During your consultation, the doctor will also explain the suitable treatment options and estimated cost based on your condition.

question: I had an ectopic pregnancy, what are the options for conception?
answer: We’re truly sorry to hear that. In ectopic pregnancy, the baby starts growing in the fallopian tube, which sometimes leads to the removal of the tube, making natural pregnancy difficult. IVF is usually the best option in such cases. In IVF, the fertilization process is done in the lab instead of the fallopian tube, and then the embryo is transferred into the uterus. This increases the chances of a successful pregnancy. We suggest you visit the center and consult our doctor who will guide you through the process in detail after checking your reports.

question: I’ve already had an unsuccessful IVF at another hospital – is there any hope or other option now?
answer: Sir/Ma’am, we truly understand how emotionally and physically challenging multiple IVF failures can be. Many patients come to us after IVF failures at other hospitals. Please don’t lose hope—you’ve contacted the right place. At IVF, we offer advanced treatments like Laser-Assisted Hatching, Blastocyst Culture, Pre-genetic Testing, PRP, ICSI, and IMSI, which increase your chances of success. That’s why our IVF success rate is 70–75%. We suggest visiting with your previous reports. Our doctors will study them, identify why the IVF failed, and recommend a better treatment plan. Many patients who had 3–5 failed IVF cycles elsewhere have conceived successfully with us on their first attempt. So please visit us once—we’re confident our expert team will guide you toward the right solution.

question: I already have one baby but can’t conceive again – why?
answer: This condition is known as secondary infertility. It can occur due to age, lifestyle changes, uterine or sperm issues. A proper diagnosis will help us understand the cause and start the right treatment. It’s important to consult with our doctor so they can evaluate your case and identify the exact reason. During your consultation, the doctor will also explain the suitable treatment options.

question: What if the patient has weak endometrial lining?
answer: The endometrial lining is essential for embryo implantation. If it’s weak, we often suggest PRP (Platelet-Rich Plasma) therapy. This helps in improving the thickness and quality of the lining. Our doctors will recommend the best approach after evaluation.

question: It’s been 2 years of marriage, but I’m unable to conceive – what can be the reason?
answer: There can be several reasons like blocked fallopian tubes, hormonal imbalance, PCOD, low sperm count, or even stress and lifestyle issues. The best way to find out is by doing a full fertility check-up. But before that, it’s important to visit the clinic for a consultation. During the consultation, the doctor will review your case, understand your condition, and tell you the exact reason why you haven’t been able to conceive. Based on that, they’ll guide you toward the right treatment. If there’s no major issue, you may be able to try IUI. And if needed, IVF could also be a helpful option. So don’t worry—we’re here to support you with the best possible guidance.

question: Is a single visit possible at your center?
answer: Yes, you can definitely visit the center for a single consultation. For that, you’ll need to register with a fee of ₹1,000, which will remain valid for six months.

question: I live far from your center – how can I manage travel?
answer: We completely understand your concern but IVF treatment doesn't require daily hospital visits. After your first consultation, our doctors will create a personalized treatment plan that minimizes your travel. Most appointments are pre-scheduled and short, so you won’t have to stay here for long. Many of our patients travel from different cities, and we ensure the process is smooth and convenient for them. You’ll be guided at every step to make your journey as comfortable as possible.

question: What is PCOD and how does it affect fertility?
answer: PCOD (Polycystic Ovarian Disease) is a condition that causes hormonal imbalance and irregular ovulation, which can make it harder to conceive naturally. However, please don’t lose hope—PCOD is one of the most common and treatable causes of infertility. With timely lifestyle changes, medications, and the right fertility treatments like IVF, many women with PCOD go on to have successful pregnancies. Our doctors will first evaluate your case and then guide you toward the most suitable treatment plan.

question: I’ve had low sperm count for 3 years with no results – what should I do?
answer: We understand how difficult this journey can be. If medications haven't worked so far, don't lose hope, there are still effective treatment options available. In cases of low sperm count, advanced techniques like IUI  or IVF have shown great success. At IVF, we specialize in treating infertility with the latest technology and personalized care. Once you visit our center, our fertility experts will review your medical history and reports in detail, then guide you toward the best treatment plan based on your condition. Many couples with similar challenges have successfully conceived with the right approach. You're not alone—and with the right guidance, pregnancy is possible. We encourage you to take that first step and come in for a consultation.

question: I have zero sperm count – can I still become a father?
answer: Yes, it may still be possible. We’ll first do an Azoospermia test to check if sperm production is happening inside the body. If sperm are found, we can retrieve them using a procedure called TESA and use them for IVF with ICSI.If no sperm are present, then donor sperm IVF is also an option. For the best guidance, we recommend visiting for a consultation—our doctor will explain the exact condition and the most suitable treatment for you.

question: What is AMH and how does it affect fertility?
answer: AMH (Anti-Müllerian Hormone) is a hormone that shows how many eggs a woman has in her ovaries. If your AMH level is low, it means your egg count is also low, which can make it harder to get pregnant naturally.But don’t worry—pregnancy is still possible. In such cases, IVF is usually the best option. With IVF, we can carefully collect and use the best quality eggs to help you conceive. Our doctors will guide you with the right plan based on your AMH level.

question: What are the options after menopause?
answer: After menopause, a woman naturally stops having periods and can’t conceive on her own. But don’t worry—you’ve contacted the right place. At IVF, we have several advanced treatment options available even after menopause.First, you’ll need to consult with our doctor. They’ll check whether pregnancy is possible using your own eggs, and if not, there are other options like donor egg IVF. Everything will be clearly explained based on your condition. So we recommend visiting the center at the right time to get the best guidance and treatment plan for you.

question: We’ve had multiple failed IUIs from another hospital – what are the next options?
answer: We completely understand your concern. Sometimes IUI fails due to reasons like lab quality, treatment protocol, or individual medical conditions. At IVF, many patients have conceived successfully even after 2–3 failed IUIs elsewhere—thanks to our advanced labs and experienced doctors. You can visit us once with your reports. Our doctors will evaluate why IUI didn’t work for you and whether it can still be tried again, or if IVF would be a better option in your case.Our goal is to give you the right treatment at the right time, so your effort, time, and money don’t go to waste.

However, IVF is a very advanced and sensitive treatment, and it should be done with precision and proper expertise. Before starting treatment at any center, we suggest checking a few important things—like how experienced the doctors are, what kind of lab and technology they use, what their success rate is, and whether they follow standard protocols during treatment. Our doctors will guide you honestly based on your reports. After that, it’s completely your decision to go ahead where you feel confident. And sir, just like we compare things before buying even a phone, you should be fully informed when choosing the right hospital for such an important treatment. IVF will be happy to support you in every way possible.

question: Husband is HIV positive, and wife’s reports are normal — is our treatment possible?
answer: As you mentioned that the husband is HIV positive, please don’t worry — it is still possible to become a father. Our doctors will carefully review all medical reports and suggest the safest treatment plan to ensure the child is not at risk of HIV transmission. We recommend consulting our IVF specialist, who has experience handling such cases successfully in the past.

question: We have a genetic problem and are unable to conceive — what options are available?
answer: As you mentioned you’re facing a genetic issue, rest assured that we have an effective solution. Through advanced genetic testing, we select a healthy embryo that is free from any genetic disorders. This embryo is then used in the IVF process, ensuring your future child remains healthy and does not inherit the condition. For further guidance, we suggest a consultation with our IVF specialist, who will provide personalized advice based on your case.

question: We are visiting for the first time — what are the consultation and check-up charges, and what documents should we bring?
answer: For your first visit, both husband and wife should come together. Please bring your Aadhaar cards, passport-size photographs, and any previous medical reports if available. Your first consultation will be free, and basic tests and registration will be done for just ₹2,000. If the doctor recommends any advanced or additional tests, please keep around ₹5,000–₹7,000 as a buffer for those.

question: My wife has blocked tubes, and we need to get them opened. Do you perform this procedure at your hospital?
answer: Sir, instead of opening the tubes, IVF is usually a more effective option, as the success rate is higher. When a woman’s fallopian tubes are blocked, the tiny hair-like cells (cilia) inside the tubes often get damaged. This can lead to complications like ectopic pregnancy. With IVF, the fertilization happens outside the body in a lab, and the embryo is directly transferred into the uterus — bypassing the tubes entirely and improving the chances of a successful and healthy pregnancy.

question: Does IVF treatment have any side effects on the body or the baby? I have heard that babies are delivered abnormal?
answer: No ma'am, please don’t worry. IVF is a very safe and advanced treatment. There is no harm to either the mother or the baby before or after the treatment. The stimulation injections used in IVF are completely safe and generally have no side effects. IVF babies are just as healthy as naturally conceived babies — they are not born abnormal.

question: When will I get semen test reports after the sample test?
answer: Sir, the semen test process usually takes around 2 to 3 hours. So, after you submit your sample during your visit, you can expect to receive the report within 2 to 3 hours.

question: Do you offer surrogacy at your hospital? What is the process?
answer: Sir, surrogacy is usually offered to patients whose female partner does not have a uterus. If this is the case with you, we sincerely apologize as treatment is not possible here. Currently, we do not provide surrogacy services, as the process banned.

question: International patient enquiry related to infertility issues and what is the process?
answer: Sir, I will provide you with the contact number of our international department. You can speak with them directly to get all the details. Alternatively, you can also share your WhatsApp number with me, and our international team will contact you to explain the entire process for treatment and appointment.

question: is it free on first ivf check up or what is the charges on first ivf visit or what document should i carry on first ivf visit?
answer: For your first visit, both husband and wife should come together. Please bring your Aadhaar cards, passport-size photographs, and any previous medical reports if available. Your first consultation will be free, and basic tests and registration will be done for just ₹2,000. If the doctor recommends any advanced or additional tests, please keep around ₹5,000–₹7,000 as a buffer for those.

question: what are the packages offered for IUI?
answer:
The cost of the IUI Program at IVF starts from ₹5,000*.
*Cost of treatment depends on your test reports, type of treatment required, hormonal conditions etc. and may vary from couple to couple.

question: How Many Embryos Are Transferred in an IVF Cycle?
answer: The number of embryos to be transferred during an IVF cycle is dependent on a few factors, and the age of the woman is one of the most important determinants. Here's an approximate idea of the number of embryos that can be transferred based on the age of the woman, but it may vary based on the clinic and the individual case.Below 30 : Not more than one embryo transfer is recommended.Between 30-35 : Not more than 2 embryos are recommended to be transferred.Above 35 : More than 2 embryos may be transferred.

question: What are the Types of Embryo Transfers?
answer: Embryo transfer can be done in a few different ways, among which one option can be chosen by the fertility doctor for optimal outcome. 1. Frozen Embryo Transfers (FETs) Frozen embryo transfer is the most common type of embryo transfer process as it allows genetic testing of embryos before implantation, which enhances the chances of success with low risk of genetic defect or miscarriage. It involves thawing a frozen embryo and placing it past the cervix into the uterus. 2. Fresh Embryo Transfers (ETs) After the embryos have been fertilised and monitored for five to six days, they will be transferred back into the uterus of the female patient. 3. Day 3 Embryo Transfer Many embryos may not survive till day 5, so fertility doctors may transfer the embryos back to the uterus on the third day to ensure that implantation can occur and the patient can conceive successfully. 4. Day 5 Embryo Transfer This is considered the best time for embryo transfer, as this is when the blastocyst has formed.

question: What is IVF Embryo Transfer?
answer: For pregnancy to occur naturally, a sperm has to travel through the uterus and fertilise the egg present in one of the fallopian tubes. The resulting embryo must be of viable quality to be implanted in the uterus and allow pregnancy to occur. Although the process sounds quite simple, fertilization may fail to occur as there are a multitude of factors that may impede successful fertilization, such as low sperm count, blocked or compromised fallopian tubes, a damaged or diseased uterus, or suboptimal egg or sperm production or quality. When natural fertilization is hindered, this is where IVF facilitates a successful pregnancy.

question: When is Embryo Transfer Done in IVF?
answer: Embryo transfer during an IVF cycle can be done during different milestones of an IVF cycle. Typically, two days (day 3 and day 5) out of the entire IVF cycle have been earmarked for transfer. The embryo transfer process can be done on either the third or fifth day, depending on the individual circumstances of the patient, as decided by the treating fertility doctor. Day 5 embryo transfer is the most common and suitable for IVF.

question: What are the Benefits & Risks of Embryo Transfer in IVF?
answer: Before deciding upon the type of embryo transfer to be opted for, there are various factors to be considered for the best outcomes. While using frozen or fresh embryos both has its individual merits; they also have certain downsides. You should note that mild cramping and vaginal bleeding are common after embryo transfer, but there are more severe side effects, such as infection and perforation of the uterus, which are incredibly rare. Here are some benefits of embryo transfer that parents should know about. It provides the opportunity to achieve pregnancy and enjoy the journey just as with any other pregnancy It reduces the risk of inherited genetic diseases, such as Down syndrome, sickle cell anaemia, etc., due to genetic testing before embryo transfer is done. With frozen embryos, couples can choose to undergo a subsequent pregnancy at a later time by planning beforehand. Preimplantation genetic testing before embryo transfer can also help prevent miscarriages, thereby increasing the chances of a healthy pregnancy and safe childbirth. While embryo transfer offers the benefits of a safe pregnancy, parents should also be aware of the potential risks, which include the following: There is a risk of blood clot formation due to hormonal stimulation for IVF. There is a risk of losing embryos during the transfer process or even a failure of embryo implantation Twin pregnancy is common with IVFs and is known to be a higher-risk pregnancy.

question: Step-by-Step IVF & Embryo Transfer Process
answer: The embryo transfer process is quite similar to a pap smear procedure, often lasting for about 15 to 30 minutes. Here's a tentative step-by-step guide for the embryo transfer process. At the beginning of the process, a speculum is inserted into the intended mother's vagina with ultrasound to allow greater accuracy during the embryo transfer process. Subsequently, the doctor passes a catheter through the cervix into the woman's womb. The embryos are then passed through the tube and into the womb. After the embryo has been transferred, the patient is asked to lie down for about an hour to relax.

question: What Precautions are to be Taken Post Embryo Transfer?
answer: While the individual aftercare instructions may vary from person to person, here is a list of general precautionary measures to be taken after embryo transfer. Rest : Get plenty of sleep and take enough time off after the day of embryo transfer. Avoid strenuous activities : While moderate activities like walking, driving, cooking, etc., are fine, it is important to avoid running, jogging, cycling, and other strenuous activities. Diet : Patients should eat a balanced diet and avoid processed foods. They should also take supplements on time, as recommended by the doctors. Sexual intercourse : It is recommended to avoid sexual intercourse until the pregnancy results come.

question: How Long Does the IVF Implantation Process Take?
answer: The IVF embryo transfer process doesn't take a lot of time, and the entire procedure is completed within two to four hours, including the resting time after the embryo transfer. The process of embryo transfer itself takes only about 15 to 30 minutes to be completed.

question: Who can get Adenomyosis?
answer: Adenomyosis primarily affects women in their childbearing years, typically between the ages of 30 and 50. However, it can occur in women of any age. Women who have had multiple pregnancies or uterine surgeries may be at a higher risk of developing adenomyosis.

question: What is Egg retrieval?
answer: Egg retrieval is a minor surgical procedure performed at IVF to collect mature eggs from a woman's ovaries for IVF treatment. After ovarian stimulation, a doctor uses ultrasound-guided needles to retrieve the eggs, which are then fertilized with sperm in a laboratory. The patient is under sedation or anesthesia during the 20-30 minute procedure and may experience some mild discomfort, cramping, or bloating afterward

question: What is IUI Donor Process?
answer: The IUI Donor Process uses donor sperm for Intrauterine Insemination (IUI), a fertility treatment where specially prepared sperm is placed directly into a woman's uterus near ovulation, bypassing the cervix to increase pregnancy chances, ideal for single women, same-sex couples, or couples with male infertility.

question: What is Donor Cycle?
answer: vA donor cycle in IVF uses eggs or sperm from a donor when a couple's own gametes aren't viable, involving synchronized treatment where the donor undergoes ovarian stimulation, eggs are retrieved, fertilized in a lab (with the recipient's partner's or another donor's sperm), and the resulting embryo is transferred into the recipient's uterus, offering higher success rates due to younger donor eggs.

question: What is embryo glue? or embryo glue
answer: Embryo Glue is a special liquid used in IVF, rich in hyaluronic acid, to help embryos stick to the uterus lining (endometrium) for better implantation and higher pregnancy success, acting like a natural adhesive by mimicking the uterine environment with nutrients, proteins (like albumin), and anticoagulants (heparin).

question: What is Donor oocyte success?
answer: We report a success rate of around 70-75% per cycle

question: What is the full form of IVF? or ivf full form
answer: In Vitro Fertilization,A treatment where eggs and sperm are fertilized in a lab, and the embryo is placed in the uterus to help pregnancy

question: What is TESA?
answer: TESA (Testicular Sperm Aspiration) is a procedure to retrieve sperm directly from the testicles for use in IVF or ICSI treatments when sperm cannot be obtained through ejaculation.

question: What is LIT(Lymphocyte Immunization Therapy)?
answer: LIT (Lymphocyte Immunization Therapy) in IVF is a treatment for unexplained recurrent miscarriages or repeated IVF failures, where the mother receives injections of her partner's (or a donor's) white blood cells (lymphocytes) to `train` her immune system to tolerate the pregnancy and prevent it from attacking the embryo. This therapy aims to create blocking antibodies, reducing immune rejection and increasing successful implantation by introducing paternal proteins in a controlled way, often using a few injections before or during IVF cycles

question: What is PGT-A?
answer: PGT-A (Preimplantation Genetic Testing for Aneuploidy) is a test performed on embryos to check for chromosomal abnormalities, helping select the healthiest embryos for transfer during IVF.

question: what is oocyte preservation?
answer: Frozen oocytes can be thawed and then combined with sperm in the clinical lab for future use. Egg retrieval is a procedure to collect mature eggs from ovaries for IVF treatment.

question: what is embryo preservation?
answer: Embryo cryopreservation in IVF is an excellent option for preserving fertility for future use. Extra embryos from an IVF cycle are often kept frozen for future use, allowing couples to undergo subsequent pregnancies at a later time.

question: What is AMH and how does it affect fertility?
answer: AMH (Anti-Müllerian Hormone) is a hormone that indicates a woman's ovarian reserve, helping assess her fertility potential and response to IVF treatment.

question: what is NIPT?
answer: NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing) is a blood test performed between 10-20 weeks of pregnancy to screen for chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus.

question: What is PLI(Paternal Lymphocyte Immunization)?
answer: In Paternal Lymphocyte Immunization (PLI), white blood cells from the intended father are separated from his blood and injected into the mother. Given that both the mother's and the father's genes are present in pregnancy tissues, PLI (LIT) Therapy helps the mother's immune system build immunologic tolerance to the genetically alien pregnancy tissues. If a woman has had several miscarriages or failed IVF attempts, she may benefit from this treatment. Immunological issues are typically a cause for these miscarriages or failures. This therapy is used to address these shortcomings and raise the success rate. PLI Therapy was created to assist in preparing the immune system for pregnancy so that the immune system may assist in acclimatising the potential mother's body to foreign cells.

question: How much time does an IVF cycle take?
answer: May involve 2-3 visits:One day for check-up / Pre-IVF preparation15 days for IVF procedure (Second Visit)Embryo transfer

question: Can I continue working during treatments ?
answer: Yes, you may choose to continue during your treatment, just like in any other pregnancy. The doctor however may suggest differently depending on the patients treatment, condition and progress.

question: why to choose ivf or why to opt ivf
answer: IVF offers several advantages over other fertility treatments: Higher chances of success: IVF has a higher success rate compared to other methods, especially in complex infertility cases. Donor eggs or sperm: IVF allows the use of donor eggs or sperm, offering solutions for those with egg or sperm issues

question: Can you identify gender? or can we identify gender using ivf? or can i choose gender using ivf?
answer: No sir, gender determination is strictly prohibited by Indian law. IVF strictly follows all legal and ethical guidelines and does not perform any such procedures. Also sir, we believe that every child—girl or boy—is equally precious. The most important thing is having a healthy baby, and we are here to help you achieve that dream safely and ethically.

question: Who is the best doctor in your clinic/Who is the best doctor at IVF?
answer: Each IVF center has a team of expert doctors. The doctor available at your time of visit will be assigned to you. All our doctors follow the same treatment protocols to ensure consistent and high-quality care.

question: What all you can answer?
answer: I can help you with a wide range of IVF-related information and services, including using tools like the Pregnancy Calculator, booking a free consultation, finding nearby hospitals or centers, answering frequently asked questions, explaining EMI facilities, sharing success rate insights, helping you understand IVF procedures, outlining services offered and IVF packages, and clarifying medical, treatment-related, and consent-related terms. Overall, I’m here to guide you through the IVF journey by providing clear, reliable information and assistance at every step, from understanding options to planning your next action.

question: How do I know if I am infertile?
answer: Female infertility can present in various ways, and the symptoms often differ from one woman to another. Some women notice changes in their menstrual cycles, while others may experience irregular ovulation, hormonal fluctuations or persistent pelvic discomfort. However, it is important to remember that infertility can occur even when no obvious signs are present, and having these symptoms does not always mean a woman is infertile.

question: What Are the Most Common Signs of Infertility in Women?
answer: Many women observe subtle changes in their health before any clear pattern emerges. The following signs may indicate that the reproductive system is not functioning as expected:Irregular or Missed Periods, Very Painful Periods, Unexpected Bleeding Patterns, Hormonal Imbalance, Pain During Intercourse, Unexplained Weight Changes, Persistent Pelvic Discomfort

question: How Do Doctors Diagnose Female Infertility?
answer: Doctors take a step-by-step approach so that no possible cause is missed. Diagnosis usually begins with a detailed discussion about your cycle, symptoms and medical history. After that, a few tests may be suggested, such as: Hormone Tests, Ultrasound Scans, Ovulation Tracking, Testing of Fallopian Tubes, Laparoscopy

question: What is Laparoscopy?
answer: It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to check the pelvic organs and detect conditions like endometriosis or scar tissue.

question: What is Ovulation Tracking?
answer: Evaluating ovulation helps determine when the egg is released. It gives a clearer picture of how regularly the cycle is working.

question: What is Testing of Fallopian Tubes?
answer: Tests like hysterosalpingography (HSG), sonohysterography with saline and contrast or hysterosalpingo-contrast sonography (HyCoSy) check if the fallopian tubes are open.

question: What is Ultrasound Scans
answer: These images help the doctor look at the uterus, ovaries and the developing follicles.

question: What is Hormone Tests in female?
answer: These help check whether your body is producing the hormones needed for ovulation.

question: What are the Treatment Options for Female Infertility?
answer: Here are some of the common treatment options for female infertility:Fertility Medications When ovulation is irregular or absent, doctors may suggest medications or hormone injections to encourage the ovaries to release eggs more regularly. These treatments often help many women get back into a natural rhythm, Intrauterine Insemination (IUI), In-Vitro Fertilisation (IVF), Surgery When physical conditions such as fibroids, endometriosis or blocked tubes are discovered, a small surgical procedure can sometimes improve fertility. Correcting these issues helps create a healthier space for conception, Lifestyle Support Small, consistent changes can also make a noticeable difference. Managing weight, quitting smoking, improving sleep, eating well and addressing underlying medical conditions often strengthen the body’s overall reproductive health.

question: What is Male Infertility?
answer: One of the most crucial steps during a reproduction process is fertilization. This means that out of the several sperm released, at least one should travel and reach a female’s egg and fertilize it. If the male partner cannot impregnate the female due to issues like hormonal imbalance, blockages in the reproductive organs, abnormally low sperm count, etc. then your doctor may conclude that it is the case of Male Infertility.

question: What are the Types of Male Infertility?
answer: There are two identifiable types of Infertility in Men:(a) Primary infertility: Unable to impregnate and have a child even once in their lifetime. (b) Secondary infertility: Problems in impregnating again after successfully having a child in the past.

question: When should a male  check for infertility?
answer: Infertility is a problem in a male’s or female’s reproductive organs that stops them from conceiving a child. Couples who are unable to get pregnant even after engaging in frequent unprotected sexual intercourse for more than a year should consult a doctor to check for any infertility problems. Male infertility is less spoken about as compared to female infertility problems. Nevertheless, they are very prevalent and can be the major roadblock in the path of a couple’s parenthood. It is essential to address this problem at the earliest with an expert and start your treatment. Continue reading to know more about male infertility problems, symptoms, diagnosis, and solutions at IVF.

question: How Common is the Infertility of Male Partners?
answer: Here are some of the common problems identified in men regarding reproductive health and well-being.Block in the Reproductive System, Hormonal Imbalance, Poor Sperm Production, Abnormal Sperm Morphology, Low Sperm Motility

question: Which Males are more likely to have Male Infertility Problems?
answer: Several factors can put men at a greater risk of infertility problems. Below mentioned are a few examples:Reproductive age (men above 40 years and women above 35 years), Problems like stress, obesity, over-weight, Constant exposure to radiation or other toxic substances like lead, mercury, calcium, pesticides, etc., Excessive use of harmful substances like recreational drugs, alcohol, tobacco, etc., Genetic fertility disorders, Overheating, trauma, or other serious injuries to the testicles, Taking anabolic steroids, certain medications, surgeries, or other forms of treatment, etc., High temperatures and constant heat around the testes’ region

question: How is Male Factor Infertility Assessment done?
answer: Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) has introduced several effective treatments for infertility problems in men. Expert guidance, accurate diagnosis, and the best fertility solutions provided by well-experienced doctors of IVF help patients overcome the problem of infertility and easily transition into parenthood. Some of the commonly conducted tests for male factor infertility assessment are: Semen Analysis, Sperm DNA Fragmentation Index (DFI), Post ejaculation urinalysis (PEU), Physical examination, Analysis of medical history. If required, doctors can also recommend some other tests like: Hormonal testing, Scrotal Ultrasound, Testicular biopsy

question: What are the different Treatments for Male Infertility?
answer: IVF Treatment:In Vitro Fertilization has helped over 1 Lac + couples overcome infertility, ICSI Treatment: Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection can help in most severe male factor infertility. Micro – TESE: Micro Testicular Sperm Extraction can assist when sperm is not released through ejaculation, Basic Therapies: Medicines, hormonal injections, etc. are low-cost infertility therapies, Sperm Donor: In extreme cases of male infertility, a couple takes the help of sperm donation.

question: What is Semen Analysis?
answer: To understand the number of sperm present in the semen (sperm count), abnormalities in the shape of the sperm (morphology), the ability of the sperm to move (sperm motility), sperm liquefaction time (the amount of time required for the sperm to turn from a thick gel state to a liquid state), fructose level, abnormal presence of white blood cells, etc.

question: What is Sperm DNA Fragmentation Index (DFI)?
answer: The Sperm DNA Fragmentation Index test is done to identify if the genetic material of the sperm or the DNA has any kind of damage. This test is generally suggested for male infertility patients with abnormal semen analysis, advanced age, varicocele, past failure in ART cycles, etc.

question: What is Post ejaculation urinalysis (PEU)
answer: Retrograde ejaculation causes a backward flow of semen to the bladder instead of allowing it to discharge through the male reproductive organ. PEU helps to determine this condition by identifying the presence of semen in the urine.

question: What is Hormonal testing for male?
answer: Hypothalamus, pituitary glands, testicles, etc. release several hormones in the body. Through this test, hormone levels necessary for healthy sperm production, fertility, sexual development, etc. are checked.

question: What is Scrotal Ultrasound?
answer: The structure of the testicles and the nearby organs are checked through scrotal ultrasound to identify problems like varicocele, blockages, etc.

question: What is Testicular biopsy?
answer: This test is conducted by extracting sperm samples from a person’s testicles and checking if male fertility issues are due to low sperm production, problems in sperm motility, blockages, etc.

question: What are the Symptoms for male infetility?
answer: The main sign of male infertility is the inability to conceive a child. There may be no other obvious signs or symptoms: Problems with sexual function — for example, difficulty with ejaculation or small volumes of fluid ejaculated, reduced sexual desire, or difficulty maintaining an erection (erectile dysfunction), Pain, swelling or a lump in the testicle area, Recurrent respiratory infections, Inability to smell, Abnormal breast growth (gynecomastia), Decreased facial or body hair or other signs of a chromosomal or hormonal abnormality, A lower than normal sperm count (fewer than 15 million sperm per milliliter of semen or a total sperm count of less than 39 million per ejaculate)

question: What are the Causes for Male fertility?
answer: Male fertility is a complex process. To get your partner pregnant, the following must occur: You must produce healthy sperm, Sperm have to be carried into the semen, There needs to be enough sperm in the semen, functional and able to move. If the movement (motility) or function of your sperm is abnormal: the sperm may not be able to reach or penetrate your partner's egg.There can be medical causes like Varicocele, Infection, Ejaculation issues, Antibodies that attack sperm,Tumors, Undescended testicles, Hormone imbalances, Defects of tubules that transport sperm, Chromosome defects, Problems with sexual intercourseCeliac disease, Certain medications like estosterone replacement therapy, long-term anabolic steroid use, cancer medications (chemotherapy), some ulcer drugs, some arthritis drugs and certain other medications can impair sperm production and decrease male fertility, Prior surgeriesand there can be Environmental causes like Industrial chemicals, Heavy metal exposure, Radiation or X-rays, Overheating the testicles, Sitting for long periods, wearing tight clothing or working on a laptop computer for long stretches of time also may increase the temperature in your scrotum and may slightly reduce sperm production. But, the research isn't conclusive.There can be also health, lifestyle and other causes like Drug, Alcohol, Tobacco, smoking,Weight.

question: What is Varicocele?
answer: A varicocele is a swelling of the veins that drain the testicle. It's the most common reversible cause of male infertility. Although the exact reason that varicoceles cause infertility is unknown, it may be related to abnormal blood flow. Varicoceles lead to reduced sperm quantity and quality.

question: What are the Ejaculation issues?
answer: Retrograde ejaculation occurs when semen enters the bladder during orgasm instead of emerging out the tip of the penis. Various health conditions can cause retrograde ejaculation, including diabetes, spinal injuries, medications, and surgery of the bladder, prostate or urethra.

question: What is ICSI?
answer: Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) is an advanced assisted reproductive technology (ART) procedure used primarily to treat severe male factor infertility. It involves injecting a single, healthy sperm directly into the center of a mature egg using microscopic tools to facilitate fertilization. This specialized form of IVF is designed for cases with low sperm count, poor motility, or abnormal morphology.

question: What is surrogacy?
answer: Surrogacy is a, medically and legally complex, assisted reproduction method where a woman (the surrogate) carries and gives birth to a child for another person or couple (the intended parents). It is used when pregnancy is impossible or risky due to infertility, uterine conditions, or for same-sex/single parents. The surrogate typically has no legal rights to the child after birth.Types of Surrogacy Gestational Surrogacy (Most Common): The surrogate has no genetic link to the child. The embryo, created via IVF using the intended parents' or donors' sperm/eggs, is implanted into the surrogate. Traditional Surrogacy: The surrogate uses her own egg, making her the biological mother, and is fertilized via artificial insemination with the intended father’s sperm

question: What is the difference between IVF and ICSI?
answer: The main difference between IVF and ICSI is fertilization method: IVF involves mixing many sperm with an egg and letting one fertilize naturally in a dish, while ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection) involves a specialist directly injecting a single sperm into the egg, bypassing natural selection. IVF is a broader process, and ICSI is a specific technique often used within an IVF cycle, especially for male infertility (low count/motility), frozen eggs, or previous IVF failures, making it more targeted but typically costlier.

question: Is embryo transfer painful?
answer: No, an embryo transfer is generally not painful, described by most as quick and comfortable, similar to a Pap smear with mild pressure or slight cramping, but requiring no anesthesia; any discomfort is usually minor and short-lived, though the emotional aspect can be significant.

question: How many eggs are collected?
answer: Various studies have shown that to produce 1 euploid (genetically normal) embryo the number of eggs needed increases exponentially with age. For example at the age of 34yrs, 5 oocytes will be needed to make 1 euploid embryo. However at the age of 38 yrs, 10 oocytes will be needed for the same. Similarly to produce 2 euploid embryos 14 and 24 oocytes will be needed at 34 and 38 yrs of age respectively. So we can say that the minimum number of eggs needed for a live birth increases with female age. There is a second school of thought which suggests that the live birth rate increases with number of eggs retrieved upto around 15 eggs, and then the rate decreases if more than 15 eggs are retrieved in a single ovarian stimulation cycle. Hence they opine that there is a non linear increasing relationship between number of eggs and live birth. Especially in case of fresh transfers, because higher number of eggs leads to higher estrogen value and hence low implantation rate

question: What is the IVF Success Rates Under 35?
answer: Women under 35 generally experience IVF success rates of 52% per cycle. With top-quality eggs, a robust ovarian reserve, and a receptive uterus, younger women often produce more healthy embryos, improving the odds of pregnancy. Most clinics recommend single embryo transfer (SET) to reduce the risk of multiples while maintaining excellent success rates.

question: What is the IVF Success Rates Between 35–40
answer: Women aged 35–40 may see success rates of roughly 40%, but interventions and lifestyle optimisation can help improve implantation and reduce early miscarriage risk. However, technological advancements such as Preimplantation Genetic Testing (PGT-A), ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection), and blastocyst transfer have improved outcomes for this age group. Some women in their late 30s may require donor eggs if their ovarian reserve is too low or if previous IVF attempts have failed with their own eggs.

question: What is the IVF Success Rates Over 40?
answer: After 40, IVF success usually drops to 15-20%, and past 42, it can fall below 5–10%. This is because egg numbers and quality decrease, and chromosomal issues become more common, making fertilisation or carrying a pregnancy more difficult. Being over 40 doesn’t mean it’s too late. Using donor eggs from younger women or embryos frozen earlier can really help. Doctors pick the best embryos using PGT and blastocyst culture. Many women see success rates jump to 60–70% when they use donor eggs, giving real hope to those wanting to start a family later in life.

question: What are the advantages and disadvantages of IVF?
answer: Advantages of IVF: Aids conception for infertile pairs, Overcomes fertility obstacles, Allows genetic screening, Donor gametes enable pregnancy, High success rates with modern techniques.Diadavantages of IVF are: Emotional and physical stress, Financial cost,Risk of multiple pregnancies, Possible side effects, No guaranteed pregnancy

question: What are the Pros and Cons of IVF?
answer: Pros of IVF: Aids conception for infertile pairs, Overcomes fertility obstacles, Allows genetic screening, Donor gametes enable pregnancy, High success rates with modern techniques.Cons of IVF are: Emotional and physical stress, Financial cost,Risk of multiple pregnancies, Possible side effects, No guaranteed pregnancy

question: What are the Pros and Cons of IVF for Older Women?
answer: Women over 35 or 40 who face age-related fertility challenges find IVF a meaningful path forward. The natural decline in egg quality and ovarian reserve reduces the likelihood of natural conception. IVF provides essential medical support and alternative pathways to conception. But there are certain pros and cons of IVF: Pros:For women struggling with age-related fertility changes, one of IVF’s greatest blessings is the use of donor eggs. These carefully selected eggs from young, healthy donors improve fertilisation chances and support strong embryo development. Preimplantation Genetic Testing (PGT) during IVF examines embryos for chromosomal abnormalities before implantation. This is particularly beneficial for older women, as it reduces inherited risks and boosts the chance of a healthy pregnancy. Cons:Even with its advantages, IVF success falls after 40 because the body’s ability to carry a pregnancy decreases with age. Older women have a higher likelihood of complications such as hypertension, gestational diabetes, miscarriage, and preterm birth. A specialist must carefully evaluate these disadvantages of IVF before starting treatment.

question: How to Minimise IVF Disadvantages?
answer: Following certain practices can help minimise the physical, emotional, and financial challenges associated with IVF: Strict adherence to medical guidance, Healthy lifestyle, Single embryo transfer, Emotional support

question: What causes infertility in couples?
answer: Infertility in couples is caused by a mix of female factors (ovulation disorders, PCOS, blocked tubes), male factors (low sperm count/quality), and lifestyle issues like high stress, obesity, and advanced age. These factors disrupt natural conception, requiring medical diagnosis to determine the best treatment, such as IVF

question: Are there any female IVF specialists available?
answer: At IVF, female fertility specialists are available across our centers. Treatment quality does not depend on a single doctor, as each center has a team of trained fertility experts—including female IVF specialists—who follow standardized treatment protocols. This ensures consistent, high-quality care at every location. The specialist you meet will be fully supported by our experienced medical and embryology team. question: Which doctor specializes in high-risk fertility cases?
answer: At IVF, high-risk fertility cases are managed by experienced fertility specialists trained to handle complex conditions. Treatment does not rely on a single doctor; each center has a dedicated team of specialists who follow standardized treatment protocols to ensure safe and effective care. The doctor you consult will be supported by a highly skilled medical and embryology team throughout your treatment journey. question: Is IVF unnatural?
answer: IVF is a medical treatment designed to support natural biological processes, not replace them. It helps fertilization occur under controlled conditions and then allows the pregnancy to continue naturally in the body. IVF has been safely used for many years and has helped millions of couples conceive. The process follows well-established medical and ethical standards, with the goal of achieving a healthy pregnancy.

question: I don’t want unnecessary treatment - Can simpler treatment work?
answer: Absolutely. Our doctors recommend IVF only when it is medically necessary. If a simpler or less expensive treatment can work, that option is always discussed first.
